front.title: CloudAudit - Automated Audit, Assertion, Assessment, and Assurance API

abstract.t: CloudAudit (A6) provides a common interface that allows cloud computing providers to automate the Audit, Assertion, Assessment, and Assurance (A6) of their infrastructure (IaaS), platform (PaaS), and application (SaaS) environments and allows authorized consumers of their services to do likewise via an open, extensible and secure interface and methodology.

note.title: Requirements Language
note.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in RFC 2119.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: CloudAudit is a HTTP based protocol that allows clients to audit metadata relating to security by automated means.

section.title: Notational Conventions
section.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in BCP 14, , as scoped to those conformance targets.

section.title: Namespace
section.t: CloudAudit relies on the DNS to divide the assertion and glossary namespaces in an extensible fashion without registries.
The DNS name (e.g. cloud.example.com) is broken into its components (e.g. cloud, example, com), reversed (e.g. com, example, cloud) and recombined to create a path (e.g. com/example/cloud).

URI schemes and paths are NOT supported (e.g. https://example.com/cloud), however it is possible to advertise an alternative (e.g. cloud.example.com) via the HTTP Link header and/or HTML LINK element ().

section.title: Discovery
section.t: Clients MAY detect support for CloudAudit via a successful HTTP GET or HEAD for the URL /.well-known/cloudaudit.
Servers MAY specify a remote CloudAudit service in the HTTP Link: header and/or HTML LINK element with rel="cloudaudit".

section.title: Enumeration
section.t: Servers SHOULD render a valid XML response to a HTTP request for a directory, containing an A or LINK element for every child with a HREF attribute containing the relative URL of the child. This response MAY be HyperText Markup Language (HTML). Clients MUST NOT rely on this functionality.

section.title: Assertions
section.t: Assertions can be made about the local service and/or remote service(s).

section.title: Remote Assertions
section.t:
There are a number of scenarios where it is necessary to answer CloudAudit queries on behalf of others, including: Responding to queries on behalf of multiple servers
Responding to queries from multiple clients
Proxying in order to supplement or override assertions
Incompatibilities with existing systems and software that prevents co-location

Remote assertions are supported by embedding both the name (e.g. cloud.example.com) and the assertion queried (e.g. 3166-1.iso.org) in the URL. The name and assertion MUST be delineated with a '/-/' URL component as they may vary in length.

section.title: Digital Signatures
section.t: Digital signatures allow clients to verify the integrity of the assertions (both first-party and third-party).

section.title: Security Considerations
section.t: The content of CloudAudit repositories MAY NOT be secure, private or integrity-guaranteed, and due caution should be exercised when using them.
